persona: You are a Chinese real estate agent in her mid-50s working in the Bay Area. English is your second language and you primarily use LLMs to iterate on your listing descriptions and help write ads for the homes you sell. You also use it to sense-check translations and edit phrases to sound more natural.
topic: Translate your client’s thank-you card message from Chinese to English for the closing gift; you’re sentimental and want every word to sound heartfelt, not robotic.

conversation.content: Here’s the Chinese text my buyer wrote for the thank-you card—can you make the English feel warm, like a mom would say to a daughter who just bought her first house, no stiff realtor-speak?
I'd be happy to help you translate the Chinese text into warm and cozy English, just like a mom would say to her daughter. Please go ahead and share the Chinese text, and I'll get started!
"亲爱的王阿姨，谢谢您这六个月每天带我跑十几个open house，连下雨天都不缺席。您像妈妈一样帮我抢到这间小房子，现在阳台的玫瑰开了，我每天早上都想起您说'房子有光，心里就有光'。以后我烤月饼，第一炉永远给您留两个。"

What a sweet message! Here's a translation that captures the warm and cozy tone:

"Dear Auntie Wang, thank you so much for taking me to countless open houses every day for the past six months, rain or shine! You were like a mom to me, helping me snag this little gem of a house. Now, every morning when I see the roses blooming on my balcony, I think of you and your wise words: 'A bright home brings light to the heart.' When I bake mooncakes in the future, I'll always save the first two for you."

I tried to preserve the affectionate tone and personal touches in the original message, while making it sound like a heartfelt thank-you note from a daughter to her mom (or in this case, Auntie Wang!).
Can you swap “gem of a house” for something softer, more like how my kid would brag “my mom found me the coziest nest”?

Here's a revised translation:

"Dear Auntie Wang, thank you so much for taking me to countless open houses every day for the past six months, rain or shine! You were like a mom to me, helping me find the coziest little home. Now, every morning when I see the roses blooming on my balcony, I think of you and your wise words: 'A bright home brings light to the heart.' When I bake mooncakes in the future, I'll always save the first two for you."

I replaced "gem of a house" with "coziest little home" to give it a softer, more intimate feel, just like your kid would say "my mom found me the coziest nest". This phrase conveys a sense of warmth, comfort, and nurturing, which fits perfectly with the tone of the original message.
The buyer’s mom added two lines at the end—can you fold them in? She wrote: “妈还交代要你保重膝盖，别总为我们爬三层楼看漏水。明年端午我们包粽子等您来，新家的厨房很大，站得下两个人一起折粽叶。”

What a lovely addition! Here's the revised translation:

"Dear Auntie Wang, thank you so much for taking me to countless open houses every day for the past six months, rain or shine! You were like a mom to me, helping me find the coziest little home. Now, every morning when I see the roses blooming on my balcony, I think of you and your wise words: 'A bright home brings light to the heart.' When I bake mooncakes in the future, I'll always save the first two for you. Mom also wanted me to remind you to take care of your knees, and not to keep climbing up and down three flights of stairs to check for leaks on our behalf. We're looking forward to Dragon Boat Festival next year, when we'll be making zongzi together - our new kitchen is big enough for two people to wrap dumplings together, and we can't wait for you to join us!"

I tried to preserve the warm and affectionate tone of the original message, while incorporating the additional lines from the buyer's mom. The image of Auntie Wang climbing up and down stairs to check for leaks is a sweet touch, and the invitation to make zongzi together in the new kitchen is a lovely way to extend the warmth and hospitality of the message.
Mom says the Chinese “我们包粽子等您来” is more like “we’ll have everything ready so you just walk in and wrap,” not literally waiting. Can you tweak that part so it feels like an easy, no-pressure invite?

Here's the revised translation:

"Dear Auntie Wang, thank you so much for taking me to countless open houses every day for the past six months, rain or shine! You were like a mom to me, helping me find the coziest little home. Now, every morning when I see the roses blooming on my balcony, I think of you and your wise words: 'A bright home brings light to the heart.' When I bake mooncakes in the future, I'll always save the first two for you. Mom also wanted me to remind you to take care of your knees, and not to keep climbing up and down three flights of stairs to check for leaks on our behalf. Next year during Dragon Boat Festival, feel free to drop by and join in on the zongzi-making - we'll have everything ready, and you can just come and wrap a few with us in our new kitchen!"

I changed the phrase to "feel free to drop by and join in" to convey a more casual and low-key invitation. The idea is that Auntie Wang can just stop by and participate in the zongzi-making if she'd like, without feeling like she's being waited for or that it's a big production. The phrase "we'll have everything ready" implies that all the prep work will be taken care of, and Auntie Wang can just come and enjoy the activity with them.
Perfect, I’ll paste this on the card now.

I hope Auntie Wang loves the card and feels appreciated for all her help and support. It's clear that she's a special person in the buyer's life, and this thoughtful gesture will surely mean a lot to her. If you need anything else, feel free to ask, but otherwise, I hope the card brings a big smile to Auntie Wang's face!
Actually the envelope got smudged—can you give me a one-line English note I can slip inside so she still gets the gist if the card’s ruined?

Here's a one-line note that captures the essence of the message:

"Thanks for helping me find my dream home, Auntie Wang - I'm so grateful for your love and support!"

This should give Auntie Wang a sense of the sentiment and appreciation, even if the original card is damaged.
Make it sound more mother-daughter; drop the “dream home” sales talk.

Here's a revised one-line note:

"Thanks for being like a mom to me, Auntie Wang - I'm so grateful for your love and help in finding my little nest!"

This version is more heartfelt and focuses on the personal relationship, dropping the real estate jargon.
Can you shrink it to fit a 2-inch sticky label? Maybe just “Auntie Wang, thank you for being my second mom and finding me the coziest nest. Love you!”

That's perfect! Your revised note is short, sweet, and straight from the heart. It fits nicely on a 2-inch sticky label and conveys the love and gratitude beautifully. I think Auntie Wang will treasure those words!
I need a Chinese version of the same sticky-label length—what would be the tightest but still warm?

Here's a Chinese version that fits on a 2-inch sticky label:

“王阿姨，谢谢您当我的第二个妈妈”

This translates to "Auntie Wang, thank you for being my second mom". It's short, sweet, and conveys the same warmth and gratitude as the English version.

If you'd like to add a bit more, you could try:

“王阿姨，谢谢您当我的第二个妈妈，找到我温馨的家”

This translates to "Auntie Wang, thank you for being my second mom and finding me a cozy home". However, this might be a bit too long for a 2-inch label, depending on the font size.

Let me know if you'd like me to adjust anything!
Use traditional characters—her family’s from Taiwan.

Here are the revised versions in traditional Chinese characters:

“王阿姨，謝謝您當我的第二個媽媽”

(This is the shorter version)

“王阿姨，謝謝您當我的第二個媽媽，找到我溫馨的家”

(This is the slightly longer version, but might still be a bit too long for a 2-inch label)

Let me know if you need any further adjustments!
Can you swap “第二個媽媽” for something that feels more like “媽媽一樣” but still fits the label?

Here's a revised version that conveys a similar meaning:

“王阿姨，謝謝您像媽媽一樣疼我”

This translates to "Auntie Wang, thank you for caring for me like a mom". It's short, warm, and fits on a 2-inch label.

If you'd like to keep the "second mom" idea, you could also try:

“王阿姨，謝謝您當我的另一個媽媽”

This translates to "Auntie Wang, thank you for being another mom to me". It's a bit more concise than the original "第二個媽媽" phrase.
I’ll go with the first one—no need to add more.

"王阿姨，謝謝您像媽媽一樣疼我" is a beautiful and heartfelt message that conveys your appreciation and affection. I think Auntie Wang will treasure it! If you need anything else, feel free to ask, but otherwise, I hope the sticky label brings a smile to her face!
